suite2p.nonrigid¶

Module Contents¶

suite2p.nonrigid.eps0 = 1e-05[source]¶
suite2p.nonrigid.sigL = 0.85[source]¶
suite2p.nonrigid.lpad = 3[source]¶
suite2p.nonrigid.subpixel = 10[source]¶
suite2p.nonrigid.kernelD(a, b)[source]¶

Gaussian kernel from a to b

suite2p.nonrigid.mat_upsample(lpad)[source]¶

upsampling matrix using gaussian kernels

suite2p.nonrigid.getXYup(cc, Ls, ops)[source]¶

get subpixel registration shifts from phase-correlation matrix cc

suite2p.nonrigid.prepare_masks(refImg1, ops)[source]¶

create blocked reference image and take its fft and multiply by gaussian smoothing mask

suite2p.nonrigid.apply_masks(Y, maskMul, maskOffset)[source]¶
suite2p.nonrigid.addmultiply(x, y, z)[source]¶
suite2p.nonrigid.my_clip(X, lhalf)[source]¶
suite2p.nonrigid.getSNR(cc, Ls, ops)[source]¶
suite2p.nonrigid.phasecorr(data, refAndMasks, ops)[source]¶

loop through blocks and compute phase correlations

suite2p.nonrigid.getSNR(cc, Ls, ops)[source]

compute SNR of phase-correlation - is it an accurate predicted shift?

suite2p.nonrigid.linear_interp(iy, ix, yb, xb, f)[source]¶

2d interpolation of f on grid of yb, xb into grid of iy, ix

suite2p.nonrigid.map_coordinates(I, yc, xc, Y)[source]¶

bilinear transform of image with ycoordinates yc and xcoordinates xc to Y

suite2p.nonrigid.nfloor(y)[source]¶
suite2p.nonrigid.shift_coordinates(data, yup, xup, mshy, mshx, Y)[source]¶

shift data by yup and xup data is nimg x Ly x Lx yup, xup are shift matrices of nimg x Ly x Lx mshy, mshx are mesh grids of Ly x Lx Y is matrix to return

suite2p.nonrigid.block_interp(ymax1, xmax1, mshy, mshx, yup, xup)[source]¶

interpolate from ymax1 to mshy to create coordinate transforms

suite2p.nonrigid.upsample_block_shifts(ops, ymax1, xmax1)[source]¶

ymax1,xmax1 are shifts in Y and X of blocks of size nimg x nblocks this function upsamples ymax1, xmax1 so that they are nimg x Ly x Lx for later bilinear interpolation returns yup, xup <- nimg x Ly x Lx

suite2p.nonrigid.transform_data(data, ops, ymax1, xmax1)[source]¶

piecewise affine transformation of data using block shifts ymax1, xmax1
